s.text: The cells were illuminated with light from a 75 watt xenon lamp using a O-5717 filter cube obtained from Molecular Probes.
This is particularly true at later times.

For the P2X receptor it has been suggested that the Ca 2+-permeable channels grow in size to form the dye-permeable pores through either aggregation of channel subunits or through dilation of the existing channel pore structure [ 12, 18, 19, 20, 21].

For the P2X receptor it has been suggested that the Ca 2+-permeable channels grow in size to form the dye-permeable pores through either aggregation of channel subunits or through dilation of the existing channel pore structure [ 12, 18, 19, 20, 21].

For the P2X receptor it has been suggested that the Ca 2+-permeable channels grow in size to form the dye-permeable pores through either aggregation of channel subunits or through dilation of the existing channel pore structure [ 12, 18, 19, 20, 21].

For the P2X receptor it has been suggested that the Ca 2+-permeable channels grow in size to form the dye-permeable pores through either aggregation of channel subunits or through dilation of the existing channel pore structure [ 12, 18, 19, 20, 21].
These results suggest that COP does not increase in size as a function of time, as would be predicted by the dilation or aggregation model.

Previous studies suggested that ATP-induced pores in HEK cells heterologously expressing the P2X 7 purinergic receptor, were formed either by dilation of the channel structure or by aggregation of channels subunits [ 19].

In contrast, if channel activation causes the formation or activation of a molecularly unique COP with fixed pore dimensions, the delay between channel activation and dye uptake should be independent of molecular size, but the subsequent rate of dye uptake should be linear and inversely proportional to molecular weight.

In contrast, if channel activation causes the formation or activation of a molecularly unique COP with fixed pore dimensions, the delay between channel activation and dye uptake should be independent of molecular size, but the subsequent rate of dye uptake should be linear and inversely proportional to molecular weight.

To better appreciate the dynamic nature of bleb formation and to clearly observe the rapid nuclear staining associated with bleb dilation, we created time-lapsed movies in which the bright-field and fluorescence images were merged into a single video (Fig 2, EB.aviand Fig 3, YO-PRO.avi; Additional Data Files section).
During the final phase of MTX-induced effects, there is a gross change in membrane integrity which allows rapid uptake of vital dyes, independent of dye molecular weight.

, auto replay), and by focusing during each sequence on a single cell within the field of view, it can be seen that fluorescence increases slowly during bleb formation, but that intense rapid dye staining occurs during the bleb dilation phase.

To better appreciate the dynamic nature of bleb formation and to clearly observe the rapid nuclear staining associated with bleb dilation, we created time-lapsed movies in which the bright-field and fluorescence images were merged into a single video (Fig 2, EB.aviand Fig 3, YO-PRO.avi; Additional Data Files section).

The first phase reflects the activation of a CaNSC and a large and rapid increase in [Ca 2+] i . After a short lag, the activation of COP allowed uptake of vital dyes into the cell and the lag was independent of dye molecular weight.
During the final phase of MTX-induced effects, there is a gross change in membrane integrity which allows rapid uptake of vital dyes, independent of dye molecular weight.

, auto replay), and by focusing during each sequence on a single cell within the field of view, it can be seen that fluorescence increases slowly during bleb formation, but that intense rapid dye staining occurs during the bleb dilation phase.
In particular, this model predicts a delay between channel activation and dye uptake and this delay should be directly proportional to the molecular size of the permeating dye.

Stimulation of P2X purinergic receptors by ATP causes similar changes in cytosolic Ca 2+and vital dye uptake [ 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17] suggesting that MTX activates a cell death cascade that is physiologically relevant, although the exact role of either the P2X- or MTX-induced cascade in normal cellular biology remains unknown.

Subsequent readmission of Ca 2+to the bath produced an increase in ethidium uptake that again followed a biphasic time course, virtually identical to the profile observed when MTX was added to cells incubated with normal Ca 2+-containing medium.
The fluorescence images were used to determine dye uptake as a function of time.

Images (8-bit gray scale) were stored as averages of sixteen video frames (phase images) or as accumulations of four video frames (fluorescent images) with shutter controllers switching between light and fluorescent illumination.
The time-lapse video was created from the captured images as described in Material and Methods , with a time compression of 3.5 minutes (i.e.

Images (8-bit gray scale) were stored as averages of sixteen video frames (phase images) or as accumulations of four video frames (fluorescent images) with shutter controllers switching between light and fluorescent illumination.
For this movie, the phase and ethidium fluorescence images were merged into a single video.

To better appreciate the dynamic nature of bleb formation and to clearly observe the rapid nuclear staining associated with bleb dilation, we created time-lapsed movies in which the bright-field and fluorescence images were merged into a single video (Fig 2, EB.aviand Fig 3, YO-PRO.avi; Additional Data Files section).
